scripts.test: if port-is-free --silent 4000 ; then npm run -s _test_1 ; else npm run -s _ci_seq ; fi
scripts._test_1: concurrently --kill-others --success=first -n emul,test "npm run -s start" "wait-for 4000 && npm run -s _ci_seq"
scripts.ci:seq: concurrently --kill-others -n emul,test "npm run -s ci:start" "wait-for 4000 && npm run -s _ci_seq"
scripts._ci_seq: npm run test:fns:all && npm run test:rules:all
scripts.ci:par: concurrently --kill-others -n emul,test "npm run -s ci:start" "wait-for 4000 && npm run -s _ci_par"
scripts._ci_par: concurrently -n test-fns,test-rules "npm run test:fns:all" "npm run test:rules:all"

engines.npm: There is no single *pressing* reason why, but the two (6 vs. 7) seem slightly incompatible. Instead of being
bitten by this, since npm 7 is now stable and released, let's require it.
NOTE: 'npm@6' does not seem to observe the 'engines.npm' - it still runs!

//preinstall: There does not seem to exist a need for '(cd functions && npm install)', now that we depend on 'file:functions'
Keep an eye on it. If needed, a 'preinstall' script can be used to create 'functions/node_modules'.
ci: For the CI (as name implies), runs the tests against native 'firebase-tools'.
ci-prepare: Something the CI should run, before it proceeds with 'npm run ci'.
start: The parameters are selected so that this can be used also for front end testing:
- '--project=app' shows the app's data in Emulator UI
- '--only auth,...' starts also the auth emulator
These *would not be needed* for testing the back-end itself, but help in that we don't end up launching
two kinds of emulation back-ends - just the same that can be used both for backend and front end development.
